channel.title: [PI]connection error[PI]
channel.description:
K well I have a server and it loaded fine when I had it running on my local host but when I made a no-ip and set the client to connect to that host I can't get it to connect now. It keeps saying error connecting to server and I want to test some stuff with my friend before i buy a vps and stuff.
Yes I've portforwarded Yes I have a static ip Yes I have the server running
Please help.

item.title: [PI]connection error[PI]
item.dc:creator: @_onster мonster
item.description:
@_onster wrote:

[quote=“Majora, post:16, topic:405005”]Could it be because I have the server running on port 43594 right now?

And thanks I’ll try the windows firewall thing, when I ran the server it asked somethin about a firewall and I think I allowed access, but his computer is in dutch and I didn’t know how to read it.

Anyway, he logged off because its really late where he lives. Hopefully I"l be able to get this working when he’s back on.

Thanks for your help.[/quote]
If you’re trying to get canyouseeme.org to ping to the port 43594 and you’ve already got it running, then you’ve already “plugged” that port in, so nothing else can connect to it.

Read full topic

item.title: [PI]connection error[PI]
item.dc:creator: @Majora Majora
item.description:
@Majora wrote:

Could it be because I have the server running on port 43594 right now?

And thanks I’ll try the windows firewall thing, when I ran the server it asked somethin about a firewall and I think I allowed access, but his computer is in dutch and I didn’t know how to read it.

Anyway, he logged off because its really late where he lives. Hopefully I"l be able to get this working when he’s back on.

Thanks for your help.

Read full topic

item.title: [PI]connection error[PI]
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Majora:

it is open though… i have opened ports many times before I’m sure I’m doing it right :S

If canyouseem.org says that it can’t connect, or can’t see your computer, it means that it can’t get through that port.

It may also be a local firewall (windows defender)

Read full topic

item.title: [PI]connection error[PI]
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Majora:

Ok, the server is being hosted on his computer. It works for him on 127.0.0.1 on his computer but I still can’t connect to his no-ip.

Does his firewall (router or local) allow connections through the specified port?

Read full topic

item.title: [PI]connection error[PI]
item.dc:creator: @Majora Majora
item.description:

Ok, the server is being hosted on his computer. It works for him on 127.0.0.1 on his computer but I still can’t connect to his no-ip.

item.title: [PI]connection error[PI]
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“мonster, post:4, topic:405005”]Also, double check the No-IP address, as it’s always easy to miss even the smallest of things. Check and check again.

It is and I have port 43594 portforwarded (TCP)

Don’t you have to do UDP as well?[/quote]

No. UDP is a totally different protocol.

My general rules have been:
If the server is running on the same machine you’re connecting from, use 127.0.0.1
If the server is running on the same network you’re connecting from, use the No-IP address, or the LAN address (192.168.X.X)
If the server is running on a different network from what you’re connecting from, use the No-IP address.

Read full topic
